data.title: Ode to Montgomery major leaguer Gamble whose iconic hair will long be remembered
data.meta_description: Ode to Montgomery major leaguer Oscar Gamble whose iconic hair will long be remembered.
data.text:
Oscar Gamble, who hit 200 home runs for seven clubs over 17 major league seasons, died on Jan. 31 at the age of 68 from a rare tumor on his jaw.

Gamble, who was born in Ramer, graduated from G.W. Carver and lived in Montgomery, was known for his fearless left-handed batting stance in which he would crouch over the plate like a question mark. His sweet swing took advantage of the short right-field porch at Yankee Stadium.

He was also known for his hairstyle, an Afro that tested batting helmets and defied gravity. His 1976 Topps baseball card — with a Yankees cap airbrushed atop his head — became the enduring image of a veteran hitter and a congenial teammate.

This poem is dedicated to his memory.

When baseball is a game no more

And Wrigley is in ruins,

When white socks are just things to wear

And anthems empty tunes,

Crowd echoes will ring silent,

And ash trees will stand bare,

The only thing remembered then

Will be Oscar Gamble’s hair.

It exceeded all proportion,

It could not be contained,

It bloomed round as a dark sunrise,

It glistened in the rain.

The little boys with crew cuts

Or blond locks oh so fair

Would look and cheer with wonder

At Oscar Gamble’s hair.

The Big O was a handsome man

Who came from Alabam.

He grew up facing Old Jim Crow

And home runs learned to slam.

He led the race with wit and pride,

He welcomed all the stares,

And smiled into the mirror

At Oscar Gamble’s hair.

Cleveland let him grow it big,

When a helmet was applied,

He looked like Mickey Mouse’s bro,

A puff ball on each side.

New York paid to tame it,

He played without despair,

For his legend kept on growing

Just like Oscar Gamble’s hair.

Others sports Afros

As a sign of racial pride,

From Angela D to Dr. J

Black halos high and wide.

And me, I hold a baseball card

With sacramental care,

They airbrushed a New York Yankees cap

On Oscar Gamble's hair.

He passed this world near Birmingham

A diamond on the square

But left behind the memories

Of Oscar Gamble's hair.

If I could grow a crop like that

I'd stand up as his heir

And step up to the plate with pride

And Oscar Gamble's hair.

Roy Peter Clark began his teaching career in the English department at AUM in 1974. From there he went to the Poynter Institute, a school for journalists in St. Petersburg, Florida. For 40 years he has coached writers of all ages. He is the author of 18 books, including "Writing Tools" and "The Glamour of Grammar."
